post_text:
As we close out our third week on this day of remembrance, we are grateful for the continued freedom to learn in any setting. Click on the link below for a 4 minute visit to our school environmental education center which is bustling daily with student visits for outdoor learning! If you haven't been there recently, you are encouraged to take a walk, ride a bike, or simply visit the center as it is certainly a tribute to our special community! Tayamentasachta is open to community members after school hours and on weekends! We kindly ask that you take care of it during your visit by removing any trash you find and keeping it the natural beauty that it is!

Take a look and see if you can find some familiar faces: https://youtu.be/dq9gwrJclLg

Reported by A. Zimmerman

Go Outside! Six graders Hailey Baker and Shaina Overcash get their hands dirty by digging up weeds at Stream-Side Eco Day. “The day is all environmentally based” explains Ms. Wilson, an Environmental Studies teacher at Greencastle-Antrim Middle School.

The day included presentations from Franklin County agencies demonstrating different environmentally based jobs.

Reported by M. Smitley

Each year, students in Mrs. Ditchcreek's Child Development Two Class host Castle Kids Play School for local kids ages 3 to 5. Taylor Alleman (12) is pretending to cook with her buddy, Deagan. Taylor stated, "He loves dropping all the eggs on me for fun."

Students enrolled in Mrs. Ditchcreek’s course, develop, plan, and implement engaging and developmentally appropriate activities for the participants.

post_text:
Reported by J Gelsinger

FULL STEAM AHEAD! For all wonderful and talented students enrolled in any of Greencastle’s many STEAM and Art classes, it’s time to celebrate the work of so many of our K-12 students.

This annual event, formerly known as the Greencastle-Antrim Art Show, will recognize all of the hard work that all students have poured into their creations, with STEAM Department Chairman and Art Teacher Alexander Miller describing it as, “A culmination of all the art students in the district, and of all art students in all grades.” Public exhibition of students’ artwork is part of the curriculum for art students, but now, more hard work will be presented to the public for viewing.

Mr. Miller wishes to highlight different types of artwork and attractions, such as multiple displays, demonstrations, activities, and some film projects, on opening night, May 15th at 5pm-7pm. After which, the STEAM Expo will be open to the public from 3:45PM (right after primary school students are dismissed) to 7PM.

post_text:
Reported by Izic Saunders

Greencastle Antrim usually brings in a lot of awards but, nothing to compared to Nationals for art. Bethany, a junior at GAHS, applied for her art piece “My Dad” in the local Scholastics and won but went further on to win Nationals and now her piece is going to travel America.

When asked about winning the award, Bethany shared that she was “Really surprised, I mean I thought they might like it and I might get like a local award maybe because it was kind of a different medium then just normal paint on canvas, but I was surprised it went as far as it did.”.

Her motivation behind the creation of this piece is that “it has a good meaning because it was to honor my dad.”.

Her motivation behind the creation of this piece is that “it has a good meaning because it was to honor my dad.”.

Reported by A. Firpo

Field of dreams! On April 11th, GAPS first graders participated in their annual field day. Students went to different activity stations such as soccer, mouse trap, golf football, chalks, hula hoops, and mini-golf.

GAPS first grader, Ansley exclaimed,” I loved it and it was something I’ve been waiting for.” The anticipation is over, the kids loved it, and this will be a day they will remember for years to come.

Reported by A. Firpo

The beginning of a new journey! Greencastle-Antrim preschoolers are entering a new stage into their new developmental growth; signing up for kindergarten.

The future GAPS students are being evaluated in reading, perception, and intelligence. A preschooler named Amelia expressed, “I’m excited to go to this school, see my old friends and make new friends.”

There you have it; these preschoolers are ready for anything and can’t wait to start their kindergarten year and be part of the Greencastle-Antrim School District.

post_text:
Reported by F. Talmadge

Have you ever wondered about the holiday Hanukkah? Well this young lady has the answers for you. Olivia, 5th grade, gave a presentation to her class on March 13th at the Greencastle-Antrim Elementary school in Room 206.

Olivia stated in her presentation that ‘’Hanukkah is the Jewish Christmas, but they don’t believe in Santa, so they don’t receive presents. They only believe in the Old Testament and not the New Testament.’’ Olivia said that she chose to do her presentation on Hanukkah because her family is Jewish and that it would be cool to learn about her history.

In her presentation. She explained, ‘’My dad’s side of the family celebrates it.’’ She also said, ‘’I love to celebrate Hanukkah because it’s fun and you get to learn about what the eight candles are.’’ At the end of the presentation, she gave her class papers with a Dreidel on it to cut out and fold.

Reported by R. Gembe

In the Greencastle-Antrim Primary School, senior Lydia helps young minds by expanding on their reading skills. Lydia interns at the Primary school for Mrs. Hoover’s 2018-19 kindergarten class. “I really love children and I would like to be a kindergarten teacher”, Lydia shares. When asked what qualities make up an excellent teacher she responded, “You have to be really patient with the kids when they get stuck. You also have to be creative and responsible.”

Reported by L. Wallace
Go Devils Go! The Greencastle Blue Devils Baseball team won a scrimmage against Biglerville High School on March 14th. The boys played against Biglerville High School to earn their win. “I think the most important thing is that each player has been consistently improving during practice, and we have definitely been doing that. I am confident that we will have a good season. We just need to take it one game at a time” explains Aaron a senior on the baseball team.

Reported by Nick Pellegrino

Little kids with big dreams!
From left to right: Olivia (3), Addison (3), Lauren (3), and Reagan (3) during their recess time in Ms. Smith’s third-grade elementary classroom. They had collaborated to make a presentation about why every student deserves their own laptop. In the presentation, they argue that they need laptops “because we won’t have to wait for a turn, we could increase our technology use in lessons, and we could take it home to extend our learning.”

post_text:
Reported by M. Cosey

Stepping out of the classroom and onto the court!
Keeping the new tradition alive, teachers and staff from GAMS and GAHS go head-to-head for the 2019 Teacher Basketball Game. It was a tight game ending in a 31-30 victory for the GAMS team on Thursday, February 28th.

The turnout was incredible as students and families came together to cheer on their teachers. When asked why the event is special, GAHS gym teacher Kylene Swain replied, “Seeing the support from you as the students, from high school to middle school, and just all the parents, the community coming together to come out and see us play… the environment was incredible, loud, crazy.”

Thank you to all who came out and showed their support for the teachers as well as Student Council who sponsored the event. We are GA proud!

post_text:
Reported by: J. Steier (10th grade)

Get your forks out! The syrup is on its way! While it still feels like winter, nature is blooming in the district. Last week, Mrs. Barnes’ AP Environmental Science class collected sap from the maple trees at Tayamentasachta.

As seen above Leigh (12) and Madelyn (12) set up the tap to have the sap flow from the tree. After working hard collecting all the sap, the students will be rewarded with pancakes and other appetizers using the maple syrup that they collected. The students are excited to test out their own syrup.
text:

Get your forks out! The syrup is on its way! While it still feels like winter, nature is blooming in the district. Last week, Mrs. Barnes’ AP Environmental Science class collected sap from the maple trees at Tayamentasachta.

As seen above Leigh (12) and Madelyn (12) set up the tap to have the sap flow from the tree. After working hard collecting all the sap, the students will be rewarded with pancakes and other appetizers using the maple syrup that they collected. The students are excited to test out their own syrup.

post_text:
Reported by J. Ellis (11th grade)

Technology is everywhere, in our homes, our cars and even our schools! Greencastle has been a part of this technological wave as well, even in the youngest of grades.

In fact, it appears that the students are being brought up learning from technology at a young age. In Ms. Keeney’s first grade class we can see that she is both teaching with technology as well as the students responding in a positive manner.

The class began with a lesson shown from the teacher’s iPad projected onto the screen. “Who are we learning about today?” says Keeney, to which the class eagerly replies, “George Washington!”

The students were then sent to use the class iPads to interact with a program called “Epic”. Talking to the students the overall answer was, “It makes it easy because if you don’t know, you can just ask Epic.” (Cooper). It appears that technology today not just changes the world, but also the way we learn it.

post_text:
Reported by R. Porterfield (12th grade)

Thanks to the efforts of GAES library aide Melissa Koons and parent Holly Kendall, students had the opportunity to talk to children's book author Chris Grabenstein. During the Skype session, students took turns to ask questions of the author.

The room light up with laughter during Mr. Grabenstein’s replies to students. While trying to be entertaining, the author also gave the students helpful advice for their futures. Luckily his books were huge hits, but it wasn’t his first try. Mr. Grabenstein told students that no matter how many times we may mess up, we have the chance to go back and improve, no matter the challenge.

As per the school calendar, there will be an early dismissal on Thursday, March 14 at 12:45 p.m. for students only in grades 6-12 for the purpose of parent-teachers conferences.

Also, according to the school calendar, there will be an early dismissal for all students on Friday, March 15 for the purpose of teacher grading. Students in grades 6-12 will be dismissed at 12:23 p.m. and students in grades K-5 will be dismissed at 1:00 p.m.

post_text:
It’s really the thought that counts. Mrs. Smith, the teacher of the 3rd grade class, prompted the students to make Valentine’s Day cards for nice people in their lives that might not receive any special recognition. Some students made cards for past teachers, some for reading teachers, some for nurses, and for a variety of others. Hunter, a student in Mrs. Smith’s class, made a card for the Parent-Teacher Organization (PTO). “They don’t usually get cards,” says Hunter, “and they do a lot for us.” Regardless of who these students made cards for, each card had one thing in common: they make the recipient smile.

Reported by: A. Measell

post_text:
Reported by M. Burgan
In her fourth-grade classroom, Jen Higgins had a vision of bringing positivity into her students' day. As she hands each child a sticky note, she encourages them to create inspiring quotes for other students to read while traveling through the stairway. "These kids need something up-lifting to read every day, and this allows them to do so," explains Higgins.

post_text: Students in Mrs. McFadden's fifth grade class are using the app “30hands Pro” to create presentations with narrations and images on the Westward Expansion. Several different topics include the Wild West, Lewis and Clark Expedition, the Oregon Trail, the Trans-Continental Railroad, and the Trail of Tears.

post_text:
Reported by L. Tytus
What a show! In this scene, the cast is singing Under the Sea, a Disney classic, as Sabastian (Spencer Mowen) tries to convince Ariel (Kyra Nadzady) that life is far better under the sea than on the surface world. The scene starts out as a simple confrontation between the two, but quickly other sea creatures appear as Sabastian begins to sing. In the end, Ariel joins in on the fun and everyone is dancing and celebrating life under the sea!

post_text:
Reported by L. Tytus
Time for an adventure under the sea! Come into school this Friday and Saturday evening for an experience beyond any other! This year’s production is Disney’s The Little Mermaid, the story of a young mermaid named Ariel as she goes on a wonderful adventure to find her true love. The production director is once again Mr. Carley, the vice principal of the primary school, who also lead the productions of many other shows such as Shrek the Musical and The Addams Family. Hopefully, this year will be another great show!

Game On!
Inspired by March Madness, students at GAPS use voting booths set up by librarian Mrs. Crider to decide on the school's favorite book character. While talking with Mrs. Crider, I overheard student's reactions to different books. These comments may suggest that newer books like Don't Press the Button have overtaken classics like the If You Give a Mouse...

Reported by B. Rudolph
Greencastle Percussion Ensemble on Saturday, February 24, competing in the home gymnasium against rival districts to bring home the GOLD! As opposed to some of the competitions' performances, which combine strong music with engaging visual performances, the Greencastle ensemble chose to focus solely on crafting powerful sound and epic rhythm. Their rivals certainly have a hard act to follow.

Reported by M. Gembe:
Brycen, a student in Ms. Keeney's class, teaches his peers about his father's job as a police officer. The 2nd grade students learn about their parent's occupations, and take turns presenting to the class. The students are not only learning about their parent's careers, but the occupations of other classmates' parents as well. Afterwards, the class is taught the significance of President's Day by Abigail, a high school intern.

post_text:
Reported by R. Porterfield:

Students Avery and Kendle, respectively, prepare water test for Mrs. Wilson's 8th grade Enviornmental Science class. The class learned how to and actively takes care of Brook Trout, PA's state fish, eventually placing them into Buck Run in Mercersburg.

Throughout the year students also gained a sense of responsibility to care and manage the environment they live in. The raising of the trout will "give them a jumpstart" in their future environment, says teacher Mrs. Wilson.

If the results of Paul's (8) test show a change in nitrate levels, the class will then change the water in the trout's tank.
text:
Reported by R. Porterfield:

Students Avery and Kendle, respectively, prepare water test for Mrs. Wilson's 8th grade Enviornmental Science class. The class learned how to and actively takes care of Brook Trout, PA's state fish, eventually placing them into Buck Run in Mercersburg.

Throughout the year students also gained a sense of responsibility to care and manage the environment they live in. The raising of the trout will "give them a jumpstart" in their future environment, says teacher Mrs. Wilson.

If the results of Paul's (8) test show a change in nitrate levels, the class will then change the water in the trout's tank.

post_text:
Reported by C. David:
Hard at work! In Mr. Hasis' Materials Processing class, GAMS students get an early exposure to basic machinery processes, and earn a high school credit in the process. In the pictures, students are working on constructing Morse code machines as part of their unit on electromagnetism. Hasis says the purpose of the class is to "Make the students generally more well-rounded individuals."

post_text: Wow this is neat! Mr. Baine currently is working his way towards obtaining a master's degree in education. He explains that he applies what he learns in college to how he teaches his students in class. One of these methods is the Google Classroom, an app that allows him to create and grade assignments with ease, all the while keeping his class engaged and connected. "The hard part," he says, "is trying to keep the students engaged in what they are learning. Technology has become a large part of the children's lives and these programs allow me teach the students in the most effective way possible."
text: Wow this is neat! Mr. Baine currently is working his way towards obtaining a master's degree in education. He explains that he applies what he learns in college to how he teaches his students in class. One of these methods is the Google Classroom, an app that allows him to create and grade assignments with ease, all the while keeping his class engaged and connected. "The hard part," he says, "is trying to keep the students engaged in what they are learning. Technology has become a large part of the children's lives and these programs allow me teach the students in the most effective way possible."

post_text:
Reported by L. Tytus
Now this is a fun way to learn. The picture above shows a website program called StoryboardThat. The program is a comic-book style storyboard creator, designed to incorporate newly learned vocab words. The 5th grade students of Mr. Baine's class, first match the vocab words to their definitions which in turn unlocks the ability to add characters and dialogue bubbles from any time period. The program allows the kids to engage with the content they are learning in a fun and creative way that improves engagement and class interaction.

post_text:
Reported by L. Tytus:
What a cool class to be in! Mr. Baine, a 5th grade teacher in the Greencastle-Antrim Elementary School, is teaching his class about Rosa Parks, a prominent historical figure who protested the unfair and prejudiced bus policies of the 1960s. He explains that his kids are practicing their interpreting skills by using multiple platforms of learning, such as their textbooks and several online resources to learn about the prominent female figure.

post_text:
5th-7th Grade Volleyball League
Starts: September 1st
Ends: October 20th

Cost: $40 (includes a t-shirt)
Where: GA High School Gym

Runs every Friday after school for 6 sessions, no league on September 22nd or October 6th.

Youth Night: October 5th, Home game vs Mechanicsburg

Participants will be walked over to the High School by coaching staff, and will need to be picked up from the gym at 5PM.

We will start by teaching the skills of the game and then will separate into teams to play against each other. Teams will be lead by current GAHS volleyball players and coaching staff.

Youth Night: October 5th, Home game vs Mechanicsburg

Participants will be walked over to the High School by coaching staff, and will need to be picked up from the gym at 5PM.

We will start by teaching the skills of the game and then will separate into teams to play against each other. Teams will be lead by current GAHS volleyball players and coaching staff.
